text:
hi folks! curious if anyone here has ever made a decision to move from a content marketing manager role to a writer/editor/editorial role, or vice versa, and how and why you made your decision. i've held a handful of content marketing manager roles, and they appeal to my strategic side; i've also been a freelance content writer and loved my smaller, more creative scope.

i'm on a small team now as a senior content marketing manager and am reflecting on how i'd like my role to progress—i often catch myself thinking i want to "just" be a writer, and i believe that's because i'm not super into the leadership aspect of my current role. i really dislike the "spotlight" that i feel in leading teams and meetings (despite doing a pretty good job of it, again due to my strategic side).

TL;DR: how do you know if you want to be a content marketing manager vs. content writer?

elements.text:

i'm on a small team now as a senior content marketing manager and am reflecting on how i'd like my role to progress—i often catch myself thinking i want to "just" be a writer, and i believe that's because i'm not super into the leadership aspect of my current role. i really dislike the "spotlight" that i feel in leading teams and meetings (despite doing a pretty good job of it, again due to my strategic side).

TL;DR: how do you know if you want to be a content marketing manager vs. content writer?

text:
The individual contributor path is great and worthwhile and no one should ever feel bad about choosing it :slightly_smiling_face:

My personal experience was dragging my feet on people management for years until I finally got the hang of it, and realizing I like it very much. All things content came easily to me in a way that leading teams did not, but that's not always a reason to _not_ pursue something.

I struggled a lot with the "spotlight" thing too. I don't like presenting, I often get shaky and have trouble breathing if I"m presenting to more than 5 people :woman-shrugging: It's annoying and stressful and makes my audience uncomfortable :sweat_smile:

I'm now at a writing-first very remote company -- we're building strong habits around using meeting time to discuss (not present) and documenting our  thinking. This environment works so well for me and a I'm finding "leading" is more about communication than some kind of charisma :slightly_smiling_face:

Again, all my personal experience that may or may not be useful or relevant to what your working through.

user_profile.real_name: Janessa Lantz, VP of Marketing at dbt Labs
user_profile.name: janessalantz

text: ^ +1 to Comms. I'm finding more of that work falling on my lap.

elements.text: ^ +1 to Comms. I'm finding more of that work falling on my lap.

text:
_highly_ relevant, <@UJG12DM1V>, thank you! that culture sounds like precisely what i'd need to really thrive as a leader, and i should say, i'm in a very supportive and flexible culture right now myself—which is why i feel like i have room to shape my role and dictate how i'd most like to contribute. my manager has been out on parental leave the past three months and i've needed to step up into bigger leadership responsibilities ... and i haven't loved it. :slightly_smiling_face: i've always been down with the IC path and have never aspired to management, and i'm not formally managing now either, to be clear—just doing a lot of leading. i find myself _accidentally_ leading and taking ownership a lot, actually. :grimacing:

lately i've really been wanting to "go back" to solo, creative work, and thinking i should let my manager know that upon her return. but something is making me feel less than 100% about that declaration... :thinking_face:
